title: Clair de Lune

musicalLanguage.description: The third movement of Debussy's Suite bergamasque (1890/1905), inspired by Paul Verlaine's poem of the same name. Clair de Lune — moonlight — is among the most beloved piano pieces ever written. The opening section floats a bare, singing melody over gently sustained harmonies, evoking moonlight on still water.
musicalLanguage.structure: Three sections: A (gentle opening melody, pp), B (flowing arpeggiated middle section), A' (return of the opening, transformed). This arrangement covers the opening A section — the most iconic passage.
keyMoments: Measures 1-2: the melody enters alone, unaccompanied — a voice in the dark
Measure 3: the bass enters with low Db, grounding the floating melody
The melody's gentle ascent to Eb5 and F5 — the highest, brightest point, like moonlight breaking through
Measures 11-12: the harmony shifts to Bbm and Gb, adding depth and shadow
The final measures settle back to Db major — the moonlight finding its reflection
teachingGoals: Playing in Db major — 5 flats (Db Eb F Gb Ab Bb C), requiring comfort with black keys
9/8 time: feel the music in three groups of three eighth notes per measure
Extreme dynamic control — the opening is pp, barely audible, like a whisper
Melodic shaping: the melody must sing above the bass, connected and flowing
Pedaling: long sustain pedal to let harmonies blend, changing with the bass
styleTips: Imagine actual moonlight — silver, cool, endlessly patient
The melody should sound like it's floating, not walking. No rhythmic emphasis.
Each group of three eighth notes should flow like water, not tick like a clock
The bass notes are like the earth — deep, dark, barely moving while the melody drifts above
Debussy said: 'Music is the silence between the notes.' Honor the rests.

measures.rightHand: R:e Bb4:e C5:e Db5:e C5:e Bb4:e Ab4:e Bb4:e R:e
measures.leftHand: R:e R:e R:e R:e R:e R:e R:e R:e R:e
measures.teachingNote: The melody enters alone — no accompaniment. Bb4 rises gently through C5 to Db5, then falls back. This is the voice of moonlight, tentative and pure. Nine eighth notes in 9/8, three groups of three.

measures.rightHand: Gb4:e Ab4:e Bb4:e C5:e Bb4:e Ab4:e Gb4:e Ab4:e R:e
measures.leftHand: R:e R:e R:e R:e R:e R:e R:e R:e R:e
measures.teachingNote: The melody dips lower — Gb4 to Ab4, rises through Bb4 to C5, then gently descends. Still alone, still pp. The Gb gives a dark, rich quality unique to Db major.

measures.rightHand: Bb4:e C5:e Db5:e Eb5:e Db5:e C5:e Bb4:e Ab4:e Bb4:e
measures.teachingNote: The bass enters — low Db3 and Ab2, deep and sustained. The melody rises higher this time, reaching Eb5 — a new peak. The moonlight grows brighter. Bass notes on beats 1 and 4, letting the harmony ring.

measures.rightHand: Db5:h C5:e Bb4:e C5:e Db5:e R:e
measures.teachingNote: Db5 held for a half note — the melody rests on the tonic, then gently turns: C5, Bb4, C5, Db5. A small melodic orbit around the home note.

measures.rightHand: Eb5:h Db5:e C5:e Bb4:e Ab4:e R:e
measures.teachingNote: Eb5 — the melody reaches higher, sustained. Then a graceful descent: Db5, C5, Bb4, Ab4. The bass shifts to Ab with Eb above — the dominant, gently pulling.

measures.rightHand: Bb4:h Ab4:e Gb4:e Ab4:e Bb4:e R:e
measures.teachingNote: Bb4 held, then a gentle turn through Ab4 and Gb4 before rising back. The Gb4 adds a dark shimmer — this is Db major's unique color.

measures.rightHand: Db5:e Eb5:e F5:e Eb5:e Db5:e C5:e Bb4:e Ab4:e Bb4:e
measures.teachingNote: The melody reaches its peak — F5, the highest note so far. Then a long, gentle descent all the way down to Ab4 and back to Bb4. This is the emotional crest of the opening section.

measures.rightHand: C5:h Bb4:e Ab4:e Bb4:e C5:e R:e
measures.teachingNote: C5 sustained, then the melody gently oscillates — a moment of contemplation before moving on. The dominant harmony underneath creates gentle tension.

measures.rightHand: Db5:e Eb5:e F5:e Gb5:e F5:e Eb5:e Db5:e C5:e Bb4:e
measures.teachingNote: Now the melody soars to Gb5 — the highest point of the entire opening. The bass moves to Bb with F above — a Bb minor chord, adding a deeper shade of emotion. This is where the moonlight is most vivid.

measures.rightHand: Eb5:h Db5:e C5:e Db5:e Eb5:e R:e
measures.teachingNote: Eb5 sustained over a Gb major chord — the IV chord of Db major. A warm, expansive sound. The melody turns gently around Db5.

measures.rightHand: F5:h Eb5:e Db5:e C5:e Bb4:e R:e
measures.teachingNote: F5 held, then a long descent through Eb5, Db5, C5, Bb4. The melody is slowly settling earthward, like moonlight fading.

measures.rightHand: Db5:e C5:e Bb4:e Ab4:e Bb4:e C5:e Db5:e Eb5:e Db5:e
measures.teachingNote: A flowing scale passage — the melody descends to Ab4 then rises all the way back to Eb5. Like a wave rolling in and pulling back. Back on the tonic harmony.

measures.rightHand: C5:e Bb4:e Ab4:e Bb4:e Ab4:e Gb4:e Ab4:e Bb4:e Ab4:e
measures.teachingNote: The melody descends and winds down, gently orbiting around Ab4 and Bb4. The Gb chord underneath adds a wistful quality.

measures.rightHand: Bb4:h Ab4:e R:e Bb4:e Db5:e R:e
measures.teachingNote: Bb4 held, then a gentle sigh to Ab4, before one last rise to Db5. The melody is finding its way home.

measures.rightHand: C5:e Bb4:e Ab4:e Gb4:e Ab4:e R:e Db5:h R:e
measures.teachingNote: A gentle descending figure leads to a sustained Db5 — the tonic, held like a long exhale. The opening section nears its close.

measures.rightHand: Db5:h R:e R:e R:e R:e R:e
measures.leftHand: Db3:e Ab3:e Db4:e Ab3:e Db3:e R:e Db2:h R:e
measures.teachingNote: The final note — Db5 sustained, fading to silence. The left hand plays a gentle arpeggio for the first time, then settles on the deepest Db. Moonlight resting on water. Let it disappear.

source: Arrangement: AI Jam Session. Based on Claude Debussy's Clair de Lune from Suite bergamasque (1890).
